Rakesh Patel wrote:

> Thank you both for your replies. You both completely understood my
> situation.

I'm glad.

> Yes, I am a top-down design sorta guy. Especially as in most projects I
> work on there is very little upfront technical design (no UML,
> Requirements specs, etc). Thats why i liked TDD, I could start from the
> 'front-end' and the design just fell out natuarlly because I was always
> thinking about the use of the code.

Here's how I recommend you proceed:

1. Write a top-level test, which will probably drive out the design of a 
few objects. Do this on a piece of paper, very roughly.

2. Back out the top-level test ("ignore" it).

3. Test-drive the individual objects you designed in step 1.

4. Re-introduce the top-level test and see whether it already passes.

Repeat.

This is not exactly Story TDD, but it's similar in concept.

> JB calls it "Story Test-Driven Development". Apart from the obvious Kent
> Beck/XP books is their any more info on this?

www.industriallogic.com

Josh Kerievsky, as far as I know, coined the term. If not, he 
popularized it.
